content: I’m a Substitute Teacher — Here’s My Thoughts on the Gun Control DebateMeagan JennettBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 25Photo by Heather Mount on UnsplashLet me start by saying two things:I love my job. I wish it paid more, sure, but I honestly think I have the coolest job in the entire school system. Substitutes occupy a unique sweet spot between teachers, students, and administration — I get to see kids in classes they struggle in, and classes where they shine; I can work in any school in our county that I want to and so have had the privilege of following some of my students as they made the transition from being the big fish on a middle school campus to wide-eyed freshmen clogging high school hallways; I’m a familiar face in the cafeteria and classrooms (sometimes the sight of which is accompanied with the groan, “I see you everywhere!”) and often provide any sort of stability (and sometimes cheerleading) for children who may be lacking that in other parts of their lives. I truly, truly love my job.I grew up in the rural south — I’m not opposed to gun use or ownership. I have friends who are lifelong hunters, friends who are military veterans, friends who use guns on their farms or in theirs homes as defense. Believe me, if you think guns are not a necessary part of backcountry life, you’ve never seen a rabid animal. Full disclosure for transparency: I’ve never touched a gun myself.

I’m a Substitute Teacher — Here’s My Thoughts on the Gun Control Debate

Meagan Jennett
Mar 25

Let me start by saying two things:

  1. I love my job. I wish it paid more, sure, but I honestly think I have the coolest job in the entire school system. Substitutes occupy a unique sweet spot between teachers, students, and administration — I get to see kids in classes they struggle in, and classes where they shine; I can work in any school in our county that I want to and so have had the privilege of following some of my students as they made the transition from being the big fish on a middle school campus to wide-eyed freshmen clogging high school hallways; I’m a familiar face in the cafeteria and classrooms (sometimes the sight of which is accompanied with the groan, “I see you everywhere!”) and often provide any sort of stability (and sometimes cheerleading) for children who may be lacking that in other parts of their lives. I truly, truly love my job.
  2. I grew up in the rural south — I’m not opposed to gun use or ownership. I have friends who are lifelong hunters, friends who are military veterans, friends who use guns on their farms or in theirs homes as defense. Believe me, if you think guns are not a necessary part of backcountry life, you’ve never seen a rabid animal. Full disclosure for transparency: I’ve never touched a gun myself.

I understand the gun debate in the United States is complex and nuanced, with deeply entrenched feelings on either side. As a scholar of American Studies, I also understand the colonial history behind the constitutional decision. I’ve been lucky enough in my life to move from my tiny, southern town, to the swollen behemoths of Los Angeles and New York City. I’m back again in Crozet (current population: 5,565, 90% of whom are white), a hamlet about twelve miles west of our notorious sister, Charlottesville. I’ve seen a lot in my brief time on this earth, and I’ve tried my best to listen and engage in any kind of productive way with everyone I meet. I’ve argued with Manhattanites against a ban on any and all firearms for private citizens, and I’ve argued with redneck Virginians standing against any kind of common-sense control. Still, sometimes jumping into this debate feels a bit like screaming into a void. What does my voice matter, really, in a room full of millions all yelling themselves hoarse? Will one more person citing the same various arguments or statistics really make any sort of impact? Probably not.

But there’s one perspective I haven’t heard in this debate — my own, and that of others like me, who walk into a different school every day.

What does it mean, after all, to be a substitute teacher in a time of increasing school violence and policing? In a time when schools in my own district have faced the threat of attack? When Parkland survivors are killing themselves in grief and guilt?

I’ve been subbing for two years now, and have mostly whittled my jobs down to two schools. The kids at these schools now know me by name, the faculty and staff are friends, even some of the parents recognize my face. In August of 2017, however, I would have told you a very different story. There are thirty-one schools in the Albemarle County School System. I knew when I started subbing that I wanted to focus my energy on middle and high school students. That narrows my list down to twelve schools. As I’ve noted, of those twelve schools, I’ve narrowed my work day even further down to a choice of two. That took time though. It took a lot of taking jobs all over the county, meeting new kids, new front office staff, new resource officers, new schedules and maps and bell systems. I can’t tell you how many times I got lost when I first started! A minor inconvenience, right? It could even be the perfect meet-cute scenario for a rom-com. Picture this: Fresh-faced substitute teacher gets lost trying to find class and bumps into a glasses-and-suspender-wearing lit teacher…*BOOM*…romance achieved.

Except, this is the real world and not knowing your way around a school can mean death in an emergency situation. What would happen if the building were to go on lock-down while I’m out wandering the hallway, trying to find my class?

All anyone would see is strange adult in a school, when the going wisdom is to act first and think later. Not to mention, if it’s the first period of the day, there could very well be a gaggle of children standing outside a locked classroom door, waiting for an adult.

Let’s say I do find my class. I’m still a strange adult, a substitute, and kids aren’t exactly known for trusting or respecting the new face in the room. Why should they? They don’t know me. Even on a normal day, I get push back from my kids. “Why should I listen to you?” “What can you even do to me? You’re just a sub.” Or, my personal favorite, “Fuck you! I’m gonna beat your ass!” I love my job, but somedays I go home on the verge of tears. So now imagine an active shooter in a building. Imagine a class (normal size is somewhere around 27 students) that doesn’t know me, trust me, or have any inclination to listen to me. How am I supposed to handle that situation? When they’re panicking and I’m trying to make quick decisions, and there’s gunshots outside the door.

Ok, so you’re not in the hallway, you have the class under control…here’s one more monkey wrench: How do you lock the door? In response to safety concerns, Albemarle County has been replacing old classroom doors with a new, bullet-proof version. Most of these doors stay locked, the only way to access a classroom is through a key or a knock. The ones that do stay unlocked are often confusing. I’ve spent more minutes than I’m proud of shoving key into hole and twisting, turning, jiggling, all in attempt to lock the classroom door at the end of the day. So here’s our two realities in the case of a shooter: Either our door is neatly shutting out any and all hallway wanderers (are we going to trust a frantic knock, after all, in such an emergency?), or I’m unable to lock the damned thing and leave myself and my class exposed to attack. The result either way is that classrooms have become closed off things, wrapping paper taped over the windows. School feels more and more like a prison, and less like a place to let young minds grow.

I was in a high school on the day of, and after, Parkland. On Wednesday I was laughing with kids as they bounded around the hallways, singing acapella Valentines to one another. On Thursday, February 15th, I was sitting on a desk in a math class, assuring scared teenagers that, yes, should a shooter burst in, I would put my body in front of any bullets aimed at them.

And I would. But that’s not the point.

I get paid $10 an hour, folks. I don’t get benefits. I have two other jobs to pay all my bills. Substitute teaching is very much a labor of love for me. This year on Valentine’s Day I found myself at a different high school, once again standing in the hallway watching children sing and dance and love one another. The resilience of children, and the resilience of the teachers and staff in these schools, will never cease to amaze me. But still, amidst the giggles, I couldn’t help but glance around the hall, subconsciously making a contingency plan. If shots were fired, how many kids could I quickly shepherd into my room? How many more would get locked in the halls? We were sitting ducks for anyone who wanted to hurt us. Was this what Parkland was like, just before a terrorist struck?

Last Wednesday, unbeknownst to me, a student was threatening to massacre black and brown students at the nearby Charlottesville High School. I walked out after school to find a ticket on my car. The first ticket I’ve ever gotten after almost two years of parking in that lot. A ticket I got, I was told the next day, “because we had a few extra people working here yesterday afternoon. Don’t worry about it!” The next day, while an Albemarle High School student was threatening violence and City schools were closed, the school I was at had a fire drill. I was told by a student later that day that her teacher hadn’t let them out into the hall until he was certain it was an actual fire drill and not an attacker tripping the system, like the Parkland shooter did.

Think about that. Really let it sink in. A teacher had to make a decision for the welfare of his kids, and he chose not to let them escape a possible fire (this was not a planned drill) until he knew there wasn’t an active shooter in the building.

In a time when approximately 550 school districts across 25 US states have cut their weeks down to four days to save costs, when I have given my own lunch to students who couldn’t afford school meals and otherwise would not have eaten, when the athletes I coach have to buy their own uniforms and pay a seasonal fee to play, and arts programs are slashed…why, in these times, are we asking already cash-strapped school districts to pay for bullet-proof doors and traumatizing teachers in active-shooter drills? Why are we funneling money into a knee-jerk, bandaid defense, when we could be taking real, long-term legislative action to curb this problem at the root?

I’m just one person. I’d rather leave the statistics and technical arguments to others. I don’t have the mind, or energy, for that sort of debate. All I can do is share my piece of the puzzle, my small perspective on what it means to work in schools in the United States in 2019. I love my job. I really do. I look forward to work every day and I feel so lucky to have this privilege of engaging with smart, funny, talented students across all swaths of cultural backgrounds and socio-economic situations. But I worry, and I know my mom worries, about what we’re allowing our schools to become. I’m not afraid to walk into a school, but I try to be realistic. Prepared, should a nightmare happen. There’s no doubt that the time for a reckoning is here. Do we believe in our children and invest in their potential as human beings? Do we protect our teachers and school staff, who give so much of themselves to their students? Or do we punish them all, an Abrahamic sacrifice to a bloated god of rabid, false patriotism?

It’s time, America, to make a choice.

  • School Shootings
  • Gun Control
  • Substitute Teaching
  • Health

    Octopuses are my favorite animals.

title: I’m a Substitute Teacher — Here’s My Thoughts on the Gun Control Debate
